repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Western Java Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Western Java
            Environmental Management Project of Indonesia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, GEO
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the risk to GEO outcome was
            high, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) Project appraisals should be
            more pro-active in anticipating the need for bridging
            advisory services to the Project Support Units; 2) It might
            be recommendable to hold very intensive consultations
            between the Bank team (e.g., appraisal team), the Executing
            Agency, and the implementing agency as early as possible; 3)
            The implementing agencies should ensure that they only
            appoint staff who are professionally qualified for, and
            sufficiently experienced in, procurement using World Bank
            procurement guidelines and standard procurement techniques
            to the tender committees; 4) A major problem for project
            implementation was the very slow pace of acquiring the
            necessary political action toward the establishment of the
            new waste management organizations, not to speak of their
            longer-term maintenance; 5) Technical assistance (TA) for
            the support of political processes should be provided in a
            more suitable modality; and 6) It became obvious that some
            of the implementing agencies were not familiar with the
            implementation of sub-projects for the purpose of loan
            preparation, so that the final result of implementation was
            a series of reports but not a proposal for implementation in APL2.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Western Java Environmental
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Western Java Environmental
            Management Project will a) lay the strategic framework which
            will form the institutional and community foundation for
            sustainable environmental waste management among the
            participating local and provincial governments (PLG); b)
            prepare detailed designs for the investments to be
            implemented mostly during the subsequent two phases; and c)
            form the basis for reducing Greenhouse Gas emissions by
            establishing commercial scale compost production. The
            project consists of four components, 1) The overall urban
            environmental management component, consisting of 21
            technical assistances (TA), will focus on drawing up
            environmental strategies for the provinces West Java and
            Jakarta Metro Areas, and then on drawing up local
            environmental strategies for the eight PLG. 2) The solid
            waste management component, consisting of seven TAs,
            includes the establishment of waste management corporations
            in Jabotabek and Greater Bandung, feasibility studies,
            engineering designs, and construction of landfills. 3) The
            community and private sector participation component,
            consisting of seven TAs, focuses on support mechanism for
            small and medium industries, soybean processing industry,
            community environment facility. 4) The composting support
            component, funded under the Global Environment Facility,
            provides subsidies to compost producers for additional
            production in the PLGs.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - West Java and Jakarta
            Environmental Management Project : environmental review

abstracts.cdata!:
This Programatic Environmental Review
            (PER) identified broad potential environmental impacts as a
            result of project implementation, and proposes the
            appropriate environmental safeguards, and mitigation. It is
            recommended that environmental monitoring plans be included
            in contract specifications, and that an Environmental
            Management Plan include: relevant descriptions of the
            environmental context of proposed sites; a planning
            analysis; and, a descriptive plan for community
            consultations, including stakeholders arrangements. The
            small and medium scale industries component, jeopardize
            wastewater pollution, currently discharged through local
            drainage systems, thus it is suggested that recycling
            alternatives, and treatment options be enforced, encouraging
            waste disposal practices. Although the program seeks to
            improve urban environment, interventions call for communal
            support, which will require public awareness campaigns, and
            educational practices towards positive behavioral changes in
            environmental protection. The input of a social
            planner/sociologist/institutional specialist is suggested to
            guide communal participation. Construction of domestic, or
            industrial facilities, with significant solid waste
            discharges, will require wastewater treatment. It is
            suggested that detailed engineering design be ensured, to
            address site-specific implications for domestic wastewater disposal.

Indonesia - West Java and Jakarta
